caption: As if Versailles was not enough, this hideaway was stunning. Just beyond the Jardins de Versailles is another beauty to enjoy.  Marie Antoinette had the perfect getaway place.

Compared to the main palace, this was definitely a letdown. We heard that Marie Antoinette live there as well as Napoleon, which was cool, but overall the aesthetics did not meet our expectations of what the palace did.

Absolutely stunning gardens, space, architecture, and history! It was such a pleasure exploring the site and learning about the rich historical context throughout the years. I would recommend walking shoes since there is a lot of cobblestone in the surrounding area.

A delightful walk from the Versailles Palace, I found the Grand and Petite Trianon to be much more approachable and like their Royal and Empirial residents, much more livable away from the Palace.  The gardens were beautiful, even in November when the grounds were undergoing off season maintenance.

Visiting the Grand Trianon was a delightful experience that added a touch of elegance to my trip to Versailles. Nestled within the expansive grounds of the Palace of Versailles, this stunning pink marble pavilion offers a serene contrast to the opulence of the main palace.  Upon arrival, the architectural beauty of the Grand Trianon is immediately striking. The blend of classical and baroque styles creates a charming and intimate atmosphere. The gardens surrounding the pavilion are meticulously maintained, filled with vibrant flowers and lush greenery, perfect for a leisurely stroll.  Inside, the rooms are beautifully decorated, showcasing exquisite furniture and artworks that reflect the lifestyle of French royalty. I particularly enjoyed the gallery and the views of the gardens from the large windows, which made for some lovely photo opportunities.  Exploring the Grand Trianon felt like stepping back in time. The quieter, more personal setting allowed me to appreciate the history and the tranquil beauty of the area away from the larger crowds at the main palace.  Overall, my visit to the Grand Trianon was a highlight of my Versailles experience. It's a must-see for anyone interested in the elegance of French history and architecture.

Rainy day isn't the best way to enjoy the trip on foot or by the train there. Trianon locates inside the garden, which requires a separate entry fee. And the arrangements of the trains are speechless. No seats or shelters when you wait for the train, meaning you have to be burnt or poured in the sun or the rain.
An unexpected area on the Versailles ground. We visited the Trianon while reviewing the visitors map.

If you are visiting Paris make time for this beautiful unique experience. I highly recommend it. Make sure you check with extra time in advance their opening days and schedule. Buying tickets in advance is a must

This is the original man cave of the French kings, with rooms of tables for playing cards and billiards. The building are beautiful and ornately furnished. However, the gardens behind it are the best part!

Beautiful!! The Grand Trianon and Trianon are a must do. Get the audio guide. Plan time to walk around - the gardens are huge and beautiful. Make sure to stay at night fall - the Trianon and Chateau are gorgeous in the evening light.
the petite one is more recommended. grand trianon had beautiful pink marble walls

What a fantastic place. Beautiful and full of history. Fabulous experience for adults for such a low price. Would be great to add some activities and animations for the kids as well as more food and drink spots.

This is a beautiful site. It is somewhat like walking through a small part of a miniature palace. The works of art, time pieces, and sample furnishings allow you to experience another era. The history and connection with Versailles made it a great site to see on the same day as seeing the palace.

It was such a delight to explore the history of all the silks used in the Versailles castle, learn a bit about how they were made, and walk around the garden. The experience is different when you visit at night and there are fewer people than usual. The visit made for a lovely, relaxing evening.

Visit is quite straightforward, much smaller than Versailles castle as a visit but worth the time, especially since you can just visit the gardens on the at from the Versailles palace to the Trianon! I would not recommend the little electric cars renting, as it is not possible to just use them to go from one place to the other, the need to be returned in the same place and are very expansive to keep idle during the Trianon visit  Train is also very infrequent and honestly you are just better off walking most of the time
THE FIRST PALACE BUNGALOW | SO PRACTICAL | DETAILS ALL ABOUT DETAILS!
The trianon is really beautiful and one should go there and enjoy the beauty and quietness of this place.

We have spent here around 2 hours. Just walked around the gardens, stayed on the stairs watching the flowers, the clouds. It is a nice castle, you don`t see the grandeur as it is at Versailles, it is a bit different, but nice nevertheless.

In the estate of Trianon, this larger palace is a one-story building that has some beautiful pink marble. One can explore the rooms of former royalty, Napoléon, and an exhibit about silk as well.  It has a unique design with an open colonnade passageway in between the two buildings.  There are also some expansive gardens one can walk through.  Note that it opens at noon and there's a security check.
A lot of walking... Take the train back to Versailles costs 5 Euros but after 20,000 steps, worth it
Cute village and ground. It a bit of a walk so take the trolley or rent a cart.
Really pretty, and worth checking out if you have some extra time and you're done with the palace at Versailles.
Omg this place was gorgeous.  I really loved viewing it. We bought the passport tickets and saw Versailles,  the gardens, and the Grand Trianon.
Very very nice attraction to visit. But there is a lot of walking to be done. Minimally 30000 steps if you wanna explore the whole place... not suitable for wheel chair I will say...

As an accompaniment to the greater complex of the Palace of Versailles, it's a good side-visit (as your ticket may already include admission), but it should be visited as a side-trip and not as a primary focus. The buildings are significantly smaller than the nearby Palace and the grounds are not as well kept. During our visit, most of the fountains and water features were turned off (expected as it was November), and also growing quite a bit of algae from what appeared to be a long summer of little-to-no maintenance. The garden/forest pathways were nice. Bathrooms could really use a scrubbing. It's not to say the area wasn't nice, but it's a late runner up when you put it side-by-side with Versailles.

The Versailles Palace is a breathtaking marvel that truly deserves every bit of its five-star rating. Stepping into its opulent halls and lush gardens feels like entering a world where royalty once reigned in unparalleled grandeur. The sheer magnitude of its architectural splendor leaves visitors in awe, allowing them to vividly imagine the lavish lifestyle of the kings and queens who once called it home. The intricate details of the palace, from the ornate furnishings to the meticulously landscaped gardens, showcase an unparalleled dedication to beauty and elegance. Visiting Versailles is not just a journey through history; it's an immersive experience in the epitome of regal magnificence.
Much quieter and less crowded than the palace, a nice walk over there too!

Loved loved loved the grounds. Rented a bike and took a picnic out around time the far end of the water. Absolutely lovely. The main building was so packed though that we could barely get through. It took about 45 minutes just to walk upstairs to the mirror room because there were so many huge tour groups clogging up every doorway. Absolutely miserable experience inside.
Beautiful place but far to walk from the main Palace. You can take transport but cost you €5 each way

Well worth the extra few $’s to visit after the palace. A good 30 minute walk away from the palace so taking the small train is recommended for handicap or the elderly. If visiting all the gardens, it recommended to start in the morning. The staff is very kind and welcoming. Entrance to the last home on the east is through the entrance to the small Trianon, so do not exit the small Trianon initially. Security checkpoints so do not bring anything of caution.

The former hunting retreat of Louis XIV that was later improved by Louis XV and XVI, Napoleon Bonaparte, and Louis-Philipe to nowadays superb villa. The rooms are wonderfully furnished. We were captivated by the furniture and other decorative pieces crafted in Louis and Imperial Styles.
Interesting palace and grounds, a short walk from the main palace, worth visiting as part of the full passport ticket.
What a spectacular morning wondering around this place. A must do if you are in Versailles. The buildings are mind blowing , the Gardens spectacular.

It's really cool palace for the queen. But for me a bit lack of information especially for the queen  it's self. I just see one photo of her in petit Trianon. But still many  things to see around the palace. For the ticket €12 include visiting the petit Trianon

The family retreat of Louis XIV, which isn't that far away from the actual palace (about 20 minutes by foot). The rooms aren't that many, and it doesn't boast with the same extravagant furniture or items as the apartments in the palace do, but it's nice to see where the royal family sought peace. Mostly into card games and biliards from the looks of it.  What I enjoyed most was the connecting corridor between the two sides of the Grand Trianon. Held together by massive columns, the corridor has open arcades between them, allowing the passer to see the interior garden on one side and the exterior garden on the other side, which leads to the forest.  There are bathrooms and a souvenir shop.  This is included in the Versaille Palace tickets.
The ambiance is lovely, and there are many rooms to explore.  It's a bit further away from the Château de Versailles, but the reduced crowds make it worth the walk.

The Palace of Versailles is well-known and well visited but make sure to leave time for this treasure. More intimately sized, provides fascinating insight into the life of the royals. Photos are from a First Empire costume ball they held there commemorating the 200th anniversary of the death of Napoleon.

After the main estate this certainly feels a let down but that is what it was designed for.  It is a long walk away, maybe an issue with kids.  There are options to rent bike or a golf cart which are expensive and can be a rough ride on the stone roads.  They rent them according to time.  It is a relaxing and beautiful walk to the place.  They have another security check there with a metal detector.
